'''Mastodon''' is an [[free and open-source software|open source]], [[Self-hosting (web services)|self-hosted]],  [[social networking service]].  Mastodon uses the [[ActivityPub]] protocol for [[federation (information technology)|federation]] which allows users to communicate between [[Distributed social network|independent]] Mastodon [[Node (networking)|instances]] and other ActivityPub compatible services. Mastodon has [[microblogging]] features similar to [[Twitter]], and is generally considered to be a part of the [[Fediverse]].<ref name="Chan 2022">{{cite news |last=Chan |first=Wilfred |title=Mastodon gained 70,000 users after Musk's Twitter takeover. I joined them |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover |access-date=3 November 2022 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2 November 2022 |archive-date=3 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221103011815/https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news |last=Farokhmanesh |first=Megan |date=7 April 2017 |title=A beginner's guide to Mastodon, the hot new open-source Twitter clone |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/7/15183128/mastodon-open-source-twitter-clone-how-to-use |access-date=4 February 2021 |work=[[The Verge]] |language=en |archive-date=2 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210402113216/https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/7/15183128/mastodon-open-source-twitter-clone-how-to-use |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Wong |first=Joon Ian |title=How to use Mastodon, the Twitter alternative that's becoming super popular |url=https://qz.com/951078/the-complete-guide-to-using-mastodon-the-twitter-twtr-alternative/ |access-date=4 February 2021 |work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |date=6 April 2017 |language=en |archive-date=2 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210402113213/https://qz.com/951078/the-complete-guide-to-using-mastodon-the-twitter-twtr-alternative/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

Mastodon was created by [[Eugen Rochko]] and revealed to the public via [[Hacker News]] in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |date=2016-10-05 |title=Show HN: A new decentralized microblogging platform |url=https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=12646083 |access-date=2022-10-31 |archive-date=7 November 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201107080657/https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=12646083 |url-status=live }}</ref> Not long after, it quickly gained popularity and became the dominant platform in the fediverse and overtaking the previous leader, [[GNU social]]. It gained significant adoption in 2022 following the [[acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=MSN1/><ref name=CNET1/>

The project is maintained by the German [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] Mastodon [[gGmbH]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Knight|first=Will|title=The Man Behind Mastodon Built It for This Moment|language=en-US|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|url=https://www.wired.com/story/the-man-behind-mastodon-eugen-rochko-built-it-for-this-moment/|access-date=2023-03-05|issn=1059-1028|archive-date=8 March 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230308041903/https://www.wired.com/story/the-man-behind-mastodon-eugen-rochko-built-it-for-this-moment/|url-status=live}}</ref> Development of Mastodon is crowd-funded, and does not contain any support for [[Advertising|advertisements]] or monetized features.

==Functionality and features==
Mastodon servers run social networking software that is capable of communicating using [[World Wide Web Consortium|W3C]]'s [[ActivityPub]] standard, which has been implemented since version 1.6.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v1.6.0|title=Release 1.6.0|website=github.com|access-date=4 March 2023|archive-date=14 July 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230714171022/https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v1.6.0|url-status=live}}</ref> A Mastodon user can therefore interact with users on any other server in the [[Fediverse]] that supports ActivityPub.

Since version 2.9.0, Mastodon has offered a single-column mode for new users by default.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9/|title=Mastodon 2.9|website=Official Mastodon Blog|date=14 June 2019|language=en|access-date=2019-06-16|archive-date=16 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210316124332/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9/|url-status=live}}</ref> In advanced mode, Mastodon approximates the microblogging interface of [[TweetDeck]]. Users post short-form status messages, historically known as "toots",<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-11-15 |title=Mastodon Has Officially Retired the 'Toot,' Its Version of the Tweet |url=https://gizmodo.com/mastodon-toot-retired-twitter-tweet-equivalent-1849786221 |access-date=2023-06-02 |website=Gizmodo |language=en |archive-date=16 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221116033308/https://gizmodo.com/mastodon-toot-retired-twitter-tweet-equivalent-1849786221 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.nottingham.ac.uk/makingsciencepublic/2022/11/11/its-not-a-retoot-is-it-moving-between-platforms-and-languages/|title='It's not a retoot is it?' Moving between platforms and languages|first=Brigitte|last=Nerlich|date=11 November 2022|website=Making Science Public|access-date=19 May 2024|archive-date=19 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240519075752/https://blogs.nottingham.ac.uk/makingsciencepublic/2022/11/11/its-not-a-retoot-is-it-moving-between-platforms-and-languages/|url-status=live}}</ref> for others to see. On a standard Mastodon instance, these messages can include up to 500 text-based characters, greater than Twitter's 280-character limit. Some instances support even longer messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/9/26/16363912/twitter-character-limit-increase-280-test|title=Twitter just doubled the character limit for tweets to 280|website=Theverge.com|access-date=3 December 2018|date=26 September 2017|archive-date=22 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210322161917/https://www.theverge.com/2017/9/26/16363912/twitter-character-limit-increase-280-test|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title=How To Get Started on Mastodon and Leave Twitter Behind|url=https://www.pcmag.com/how-to/how-to-get-started-on-mastodon-and-leave-twitter-behind|access-date=2021-02-04|website=PCMAG|language=en|archive-date=19 February 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210219234414/https://www.pcmag.com/how-to/how-to-get-started-on-mastodon-and-leave-twitter-behind|url-status=live}}</ref>

Users join a specific Mastodon server, rather than a single centralized website or application. The servers are connected as nodes in a network, and each server can administer its own rules, account privileges, and whether to share messages to and from other servers. Many servers have a theme based on a specific interest.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" />

Mastodon includes a number of specific privacy features. Each message has a variety of privacy options available, and users can choose whether the message is public or private. Public messages display on a global feed, known as a timeline, and private messages are only shared on the timelines of the user's followers. Messages can also be marked as unlisted from timelines or direct between users. Users can also mark their accounts as completely private. In the timeline, messages can display with an optional [[content warning]] feature, which requires readers to click on the hidden main body of the message to reveal it. Mastodon servers have used this feature to hide [[spoiler (media)|spoilers]], [[trigger warning]]s, and [[not safe for work]] (NSFW) content, though some accounts use the feature to hide links and thoughts others might not want to read.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="The Verge: beginner" />

Mastodon aggregates messages in local and federated timelines in real time. The local timeline shows messages from users on a singular server, while the federated timeline shows messages across all participating Mastodon servers. Users can communicate across connected Mastodon servers with usernames similar in format to full email addresses.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="The Verge: beginner"/>

=== Content moderation ===
In early 2017, journalists like [[Sarah Jeong]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|date=2017-04-04|title=Mastodon Is Like Twitter Without Nazis, So Why Are We Not Using It?|work=Motherboard|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/783akg/mastodon-is-like-twitter-without-nazis-so-why-are-we-not-using-it|access-date=2018-09-21|archive-date=4 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200904073410/https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/783akg/mastodon-is-like-twitter-without-nazis-so-why-are-we-not-using-it|url-status=live}}</ref> distinguished Mastodon from Twitter for its approach to combating harassment.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" /> Mastodon uses community-based moderation, in which each server can limit or filter out undesirable types of content, while Twitter uses a single, global policy on [[content moderation]]. Servers can choose to limit or filter out messages with disparaging content. The main author of the Mastodon software, [[Eugen Rochko]], believes that small, closely related communities deal with unwanted behavior more effectively than a large company's small safety team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/we-distribute/one-mammoth-of-a-job-an-interview-with-eugen-rochko-of-mastodon-23b159d6796a|title=One Mammoth of a Job: An Interview with Eugen Rochko of Mastodon|website=medium.com/we-distribute|date=9 July 2018|access-date=5 October 2019|archive-date=10 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210310004110/https://medium.com/we-distribute/one-mammoth-of-a-job-an-interview-with-eugen-rochko-of-mastodon-23b159d6796a|url-status=live}}</ref> Users can also block and report others to administrators, much like on Twitter.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" /><ref name="Chan and Wilfred 2023">{{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Wilfred |title= Thousands fled to Mastodon after Musk bought Twitter. Are they still 'tooting'? | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media |newspaper=The Guardian |date=18 April 2023 |access-date=13 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230602102140/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media |archive-date=2 June 2023}}</ref>

Instance administrators can block other instances from interacting with their own, an action called ''defederation''. By posting toots [[Hashtag|hashtagged]] with ''#fediblock'', some instance administrators and users alert others of issues requiring moderation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/12/raspberry-pi-shows-how-not-to-mastodon/|title=Raspberry Pi shows how not to Mastodon|last1= Moody | first1= Glyn |date= 12 Dec 2022|accessdate= 13 June 2023| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20230324080700/https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/12/raspberry-pi-shows-how-not-to-mastodon/ | archive-date= 24 March 2023 | website= Techdirt}}</ref>

=== Comparison to X ===
{{Cleanup rewrite|contains only a narrowed view of features of Twitter and the goals of Mastodon|date=October 2023}}
Unlike [[Twitter under Elon Musk|X]] (previously known as [[Twitter]]), Mastodon by default only allows for hashtags and mentioned accounts in the Fediverse to be searched, but allows server administrators to enable functionality via Elasticsearch to search for the full text of public posts that have opted-in to being indexed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.joinmastodon.org/admin/optional/elasticsearch/|title=Full-text search|website=Mastodon documentation site|accessdate=27 December 2022}}</ref><ref name="osint">{{cite web|url=https://www.secjuice.com/mastodon-osint-a-comprehensive-introduction/|title=Mastodon OSINT: A Comprehensive Introduction|last=Hassan|first=Nihad|date=27 November 2022|accessdate=27 December 2022|website=Secjuice}}</ref> Searches are limited to all content that the instance knows about, either locally or from other instances that have been indexed. However, services utilizing the ActivityPub protocol exist which allow for searching all posts on all instances as long as users opt-in.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tootfinder |url=https://www.tootfinder.ch/ |access-date=2024-04-16 |website=www.tootfinder.ch |archive-date=14 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240414114111/https://tootfinder.ch/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

For similar reasons, only hashtags can appear in a Mastodon instance's trending topics, not arbitrary popular words. Trending topics vary between instances, since individual instances are aware of different subsets of posts from the whole [[fediverse]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=admin/trends API methods - Mastodon documentation |url=https://docs.joinmastodon.org/methods/admin/trends/ |access-date=2024-04-16 |website=docs.joinmastodon.org |language=en-us |archive-date=21 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240421045901/https://docs.joinmastodon.org/methods/admin/trends/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

[[Quote tweet|Quote posts]] do not exist on Mastodon, and quotes from other instances that run software with quotes do not display an embed of the quoted post. While previously rejected from being implemented due to issues with toxicity and harassment,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-03-10 |title=Eugen Rochko (@Gargron@mastodon.social) |url=https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/99662106175542726 |access-date=2024-09-17 |website=Mastodon |language=en |archive-date=10 September 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240910045655/https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/99662106175542726 |url-status=live }}</ref> a project has since started via funding from [[NLnet]] with the goal of implementing a standard that avoids these issues.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NLnet; ActivityPub Quote Posts |url=https://nlnet.nl/project/Mastodon-Quoting/ |access-date=2024-09-17 |website=nlnet.nl |archive-date=17 September 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240917163852/https://nlnet.nl/project/Mastodon-Quoting/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

===Versions===
In September 2018, with the release of version 2.5 with redesigned public profile pages, Mastodon marked its 100th release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/09/mastodon-2.5-released|title=Mastodon 2.5 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=5 September 2018|access-date=3 December 2018|archive-date=9 November 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109034623/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/09/mastodon-2.5-released/|url-status=live}}</ref> Mastodon 2.6 was released in October 2018, introducing the possibilities of verified profiles and live, in-stream link previews for images and videos.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/10/mastodon-2.6-released|title=Mastodon 2.6 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=Blog.joinmastodon.org|date=31 October 2018|access-date=3 December 2018|archive-date=9 November 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109030725/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/10/mastodon-2.6-released/|url-status=live}}</ref> Version 2.7, in January 2019, made it possible to search for multiple hashtags at once, instead of searching for just a single hashtag. Version 2.7 has more robust moderation capabilities for server administrators and moderators, while accessibility, such as contrast for users with sight issues, was improved.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/01/mastodon-2.7|title=Mastodon 2.7 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=Blog.joinmastodon.org|date=20 January 2019|access-date=20 January 2019|archive-date=9 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210409090718/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/01/mastodon-2.7/|url-status=live}}</ref> The ability for users to create and vote in polls, as well as a new invitation system to manage registrations was integrated in April 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/04/mastodon-2.8|title=Mastodon 2.8 Highlights from the changelog|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=10 April 2019|access-date=11 April 2019|archive-date=10 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210310000240/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/04/mastodon-2.8/|url-status=live}}</ref> Mastodon 2.8.1, released in May 2019, made images with content warnings blurred instead of completely hidden.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/05/improving-support-for-adult-content-on-mastodon|title=Improving support for adult content on Mastodon|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=5 May 2019|access-date=6 May 2019|archive-date=10 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210310000610/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/05/improving-support-for-adult-content-on-mastodon/|url-status=live}}</ref> In version 2.9 in June 2019, an optional single-column view was added.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9|title=Introducing the single-column layout|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=14 June 2019|access-date=15 July 2019|archive-date=16 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210316124332/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9/|url-status=live}}</ref> This view became the default displayed to new users, with a user "preferences" option to switch to a multiple-column-based view.{{Citation needed|date=September 2022}}

In August 2020, Mastodon 3.2 was released. It included a redesigned audio player with custom thumbnails and the ability to add personal notes to one's profile.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mastodon 3.2|url=http://blog.joinmastodon.org/2020/08/mastodon-3.2/|access-date=2020-08-21|website=Official Mastodon Blog|date=2 August 2020|language=en|archive-date=9 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210409094319/https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2020/08/mastodon-3.2/|url-status=live}}</ref>

In July 2021, an official client for [[iOS]] devices was released. According to the project's CEO, [[Eugen Rochko]], the release was part of an effort to attract new users.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/30/22602275/mastodon-decentralized-social-network-official-ios-app-launches |title=Mastodon now has an official iPhone app |website=The Verge |date=30 July 2021 |access-date=31 July 2021 |archive-date=10 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211010104436/https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/30/22602275/mastodon-decentralized-social-network-official-ios-app-launches |url-status=live }}</ref>

Mastodon 4.0 was released in November 2022, including language support for translating posts, editing posts and following hashtags.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Release v4.0.0 · mastodon/mastodon |url=https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.0.0 |access-date=2022-11-20 |website=GitHub |language=en |archive-date=20 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221120001434/https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.0.0 |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Notable instances ===
As a result of its [[open source]] nature and ability to be deployed without restriction, various organizations, companies and governments have started their own Mastodon instances. While some instances have mentioned their usage of Mastodon for the service and identify themselves as a Mastodon instance, others have attempted to conceal their origin by removing all mentions of Mastodon from the public view. == Security ==
While Mastodon's decentralized structure is one of its most distinctive features, it also poses additional security challenges.

Since many Mastodon instances are run by volunteers, some security experts are concerned about data security and responsiveness to new threats and vulnerabilities across the network, considering the difficulty of configuring and maintaining an instance as well as uneven skill levels among administrators. Configuration errors and security bugs in server implementation has already led to user data being [[Scraper site|scraped]] or modified by attackers. It is worth noting that Mastodon also collects considerably less personal data, compared to other social media platforms, which makes it a lower-value target and reduces potential damage.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Goodin |first=Dan |date=2022-11-29 |title=How secure a Twitter replacement is Mastodon? Let us count the ways |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2022/11/how-secure-a-twitter-replacement-is-mastodon-let-us-count-the-ways/ |access-date=2023-01-28 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us |archive-date=28 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230128191138/https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2022/11/how-secure-a-twitter-replacement-is-mastodon-let-us-count-the-ways/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The creator of Mastodon, Eugen Rochko, argues{{Citation needed|reason=Where?|date=August 2023}} that these issues do not set it apart from other software products that can be hosted by non-professionals.

In 2023, the [[Mozilla Foundation]] contracted cybersecurity firm [[Cure53]] to perform [[penetration testing]] on the Mastodon software, in preparation for establishing an instance for the Mozilla community. The testing discovered several vulnerabilities, including one called "TootRoot" that would have enabled [[arbitrary code execution]] and another that would have enabled [[cross-site scripting]] attacks through [[oEmbed]] cards. These vulnerabilities were patched in July 2023.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mastodon fixes critical "TootRoot" vulnerability allowing node hijacking|first=Dan|last=Goodin|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date=July 6, 2023|accessdate=July 6, 2023|url=https://arstechnica.com/security/2023/07/mastodon-fixes-critical-tootroot-vulnerability-allowing-node-hijacking/|archive-date=6 July 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230706235050/https://arstechnica.com/security/2023/07/mastodon-fixes-critical-tootroot-vulnerability-allowing-node-hijacking/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Mastodon has been the main suspect in an issue regarding the generation of [[OpenGraph]] link previews, wherein the data from the link is not cached by the post and transmitted to other instances. Many instances in turn automatically fetch the preview data as well as soon as they receive the post (which can be near-instantaneously after the post is created), creating an accidental [[Denial-of-service attack|DDoS]] attack that can temporarily increase the load of a victim's server.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-05-01 |title=Please Don't Share Our Links on Mastodon: Here's Why! |url=https://news.itsfoss.com/mastodon-link-problem/ |access-date=2024-09-17 |website=It's FOSS News |language=en |archive-date=9 September 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240909155002/https://news.itsfoss.com/mastodon-link-problem/ |url-status=live }}</ref> A fix to add federation for link previews was planned for 4.3, but has since been delayed for Mastodon 4.4.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Connatser |first=Matthew |title=Mastodon delays firm fix to solve link preview DDoS |url=https://www.theregister.com/2024/05/06/mastodon_delays_fix_ddos/ |access-date=2024-05-17 |website=www.theregister.com |language=en |archive-date=17 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240517071925/https://www.theregister.com/2024/05/06/mastodon_delays_fix_ddos/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
